messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:13): ah, damn. the live-dom-viewer is down. :-(

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:20): The problem is that it is much easier to introduce cool new features unilaterally and ship them in the next version of your priprietry runtime than it is to take them through a standards process and then wait for your competitors to implement them before anyone is prepared to use them
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:22): So even though the w3c is pretty slow it's not clear that's where the real problem lies
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:22): The problem is standards, so the solution is to not do standards
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:23): JohnResig, are there any Firefox builds available publicly with support for selectors api?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:25): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: From the point of view of Microsoft that's really true. From the point of view of the end user it depends what your priorities are
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): As an end user, I want cool stuff

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:26): Yeah, clearly most end users are prepared to install Flash so they can watch the video at standardssuck.org and not worry about whether it is proprietry or not
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:26): s/standardssuck.org/youtube/ maybe ;)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:33): I guess we're pretty lucky that Flash sucks so much at basic stuff like text form controls and bookmarkability
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (13:33): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: not that I know of, I think it's still in Boris' tree
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:40): I think with the WHATWG we're sort of getting to the state of specifying competitive features in a timely manner and getting them shipped
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, IE throwing for |div and all is fine as IE doesn't support all of Selectors
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: the Design Principles document shows the power of writing things down (and of actually having principles)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:42): those were all things people fought about tooth and nail in the early days of the WG
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:42): now they are canon
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:42): that is indeed quite amazing

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:45): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, fwiw, I'd be in favor of having it without prefix, there's plenty of precedent for that too (provided you're willing to make changes to details)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (13:45): the Web isn't going to depend on it in a hurry
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:46): right

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, it seems IE8 makes it impossible to know what type of exception was thrown. I can't tell if it's a syntax err or namespace err
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:49): make sure to test it in the testsuite
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:49): e.code and all
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, yeah, it will be
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:51): today, I'm going through the backlog of issues and responding.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:52): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i'm not convinced the effort required to write them down was a price worth paying to get rob to quote those principles back at me as if i wasn't following them
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:53): it's certainly entertaining
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:54): has anyone seen any demand for a hasFeature string from implementers of other languages implementing selecotrs api? e.g. Java?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (13:55): looks for the "Don't disrupt the WG activity for no good reason" design principle
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:55): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2, look up netiquette guidelines for that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:56): ah, whatwg.org is back up
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:56): spots http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-workers/current-work/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): any chance we can get http://html5.org/tools/web-workers-tracker ? :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, why is there a new spec? Is HTML5 being split up into several?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:59): notes that web workers seems like a very silly name
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:59): people wanted workers not to be added to html5
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:59): Just becauseit sounds funny
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:59): But I don't actually object :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:00): Isn't HTML5 supposed to be in feature freeze?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:00): well, technically this wasn't added to the html5 spec, so sure :-)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:00): ok, so what's the criteria for something to be moved to that spec, or left in the existing spec?  Is it just the few things mentioned in the introduction like canvas, context menus and server-sent events?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:00): but in any case, the feature freeze is intended to prevent the spec from getting too far ahead of implementations
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker?source=http://svn.whatwg.org/webworkers/source works...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, though the links and such will be broken, so it doesn't totally work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:01): so if implementations get ahead of the spec (as they were threatening to with workers), the freeze isn't useful
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:01): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: nothing will be moved to web workers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:01): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: it's for workers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:01): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: which are new
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:01): oh, ok. What is a worker?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (14:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: webworkers still has <title>HTML 5</title>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): background thread for js
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:02): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, the introduction is a copy from somewhere else
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): did i forget to change the intro?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): oops
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): goes to fix
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:02): yeah, the abstract is from html5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): oh the abstract
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:03): abstract/intro, meh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:04): fixed
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, also, the abstract in HTML5 is wrong. It still mentions inline popup windows, which were never included.
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (14:07): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Apparently certain wg participants don't feel netiquette is part of our charter :)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:07): oh, it isn't? Cool. I should participate in more flamewars then.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (14:08): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-workers/current-work/'s <title> is still HTML 5. :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:10): I hope you don't want a multipage version of this
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (14:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: No, but he'll want it preprocessed using workers :P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:11): fixed.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (14:14): if flamewars aren't valid netiquette, then the spec should be changed to match reality
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:15): yeah, writing specs that are not implemented is no fun
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:16): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: updated the abstract
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:20): showModalDialog is sort of an inline popup
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:22): Framewars should be non-conformant but have defined error handling
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:23): <frame>wars too!

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:25): yeah, there are many things in RFC 1855 that need to be updated to deal with common situations, like bikeshedding, banning HTML mail, banning the use of broken mail clients that destroy threading and quoting, etc.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: sure, he's still irritating, but accepting your principles as the ground rules makes it harder for him to argue
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:28): remember, he could be much worse
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (14:28): and has been!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:30): it doesn't seem to have made any difference to the quality of his arguments
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:31): you know, i get mixed messages from the opera crowd
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:31): or rather, i get mixed messages from chaals relative to the rest of opera.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:33): ok. i have my web workers dev environment set up. tomorrow i shall write the spec.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:33): nn
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:34): I think chaals was asking about major changes. I agree that those should go to public-html.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:34): Actually, he didn't say that explicitly, so never mind
